revision.text:
{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{redirect|Krabs|his daughter|Pearl Krabs}} {{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox character | name = Mr. Krabs | series = [[SpongeBob SquarePants]] | image = MrKrabs.png | color = #FBEC5D | first = "[[Help Wanted (SpongeBob SquarePants)|Help Wanted]]" (1999) | last = <!--- Please do not add episodes to this parameter. It is not used for characters who are still active in the series to avoid confusion with those who no longer appear. ---> | creator = [[Stephen Hillenburg]] | lbl1 = Voiced by | data1 = {{ubl|[[Clancy Brown]]|[[Joe Whyte]] (video games)|[[Bob Joles]] (video games)}} | lbl2 = Portrayed by | data2 = Brian Ray Norris ([[SpongeBob SquarePants (musical)|Broadway]])<ref name="playbill">{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/what-did-critics-think-of-broadways-spongebob-squarepants-musical|title=What Did Critics Think of Broadway's ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' Musical?|publisher=Philip S. Birsh|work=[[Playbill]]|last=McPhee|first=Ryan|date=December 4, 2017}}</ref> | fullname = Eugene H. Krabs<ref name="Hist"/> | species = [[Crab]] | gender = Male | occupation = Owner and manager of the [[Krusty Krab]] | significantother = [[Mrs. Puff]] (girlfriend) | relatives = [[Pearl Krabs]] (daughter) }} '''Eugene H. Krabs''', better known as '''Mr. Krabs''', is a fictional character in the American [[animated series|animated television series]] ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''. He is voiced by actor [[Clancy Brown]] and first appeared in the series' pilot episode "[[Help Wanted (SpongeBob SquarePants)|Help Wanted]]" on May 1, 1999. The character was created and designed by marine biologist and animator [[Stephen Hillenburg]].
Krabs owns and operates the [[Krusty Krab]], a prominent [[fast food restaurant]] located in the underwater city of Bikini Bottom. He resides in a hollow [[anchor]] with his daughter [[Pearl Krabs|Pearl]], who is a teenage [[sperm whale]]. Krabs is obsessed with money and dislikes spending it, but will go to great lengths to make Pearl happy. He tends to worry about his riches and neglect the needs of his employees, [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob]] and [[Squidward Tentacles|Squidward]]. He is in a romantic relationship with [[Mrs. Puff]] and shares a rivalry with his former best friend [[Plankton and Karen#Plankton|Plankton]], who owns a struggling restaurant called the Chum Bucket located across the street from the Krusty Krab.
Critical reception for Mr. Krabs was positive upon the series' debut but has been mixed as the show progressed. Critics have offered praise toward his portrayal as a single father to Pearl but criticized a perceived exaggeration of his greed throughout the series' run. The character has been featured in a variety of merchandise, including [[plush toy]]s, [[action figure|collectible figures]], and [[video game]]s. He also appears in the 2004 feature film ''[[The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie]]'' and its 2015 sequel, ''[[The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water]]''.
==Role in ''SpongeBob SquarePants''== Mr. Krabs<ref name="Hist">{{cite episode|title=Krusty Krab Training Video|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=3|number=50b|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=May 10, 2002|credits=Writers: [[Aaron Springer]], [[C. H. Greenblatt]], [[Kent Osborne]]}}</ref> is commonly known as the greedy founder and owner of the Krusty Krab restaurant, where SpongeBob works as a [[fry cook]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Arthur|title=Everything I Need to Know, I Learned from Cartoons!|year=2008|publisher=Arthur Brown|location=USA|isbn=1-4357-3248-0|page=85|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X-oi8LiETHIC&pg=PA85 }}</ref> and Squidward works as a [[cashier]]. The restaurant's success is built on little competition and the popularity of the Krusty Krab's signature sandwich, the Krabby Patty, the formula to which is a closely guarded [[trade secret]].<ref name="Hist" /> Mr. Krabs frequently exploits his restaurant's popularity, engaging in [[price gouging]]<ref>{{cite episode|title=The Krusty Sponge|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=5|number=89a|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=May 10, 2002|credits=Writers: [[Aaron Springer]], Eric Shaw}}</ref> and charging his own employees for use of the building's services.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Squid on Strike|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=2|number=40a|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=October 12, 2001|credits=Writers: [[Walt Dohrn]], [[Paul Tibbitt]], [[Mark O'Hare]]}}</ref>
Krabs' rival and former best friend [[Plankton and Karen#Plankton|Plankton]] operates the Chum Bucket, an unsuccessful restaurant across the street from the Krusty Krab.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Komputer Overload|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=6|number=118b|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=March 19, 2009|credits=Writers: [[Aaron Springer]], Richard Pursel}}</ref> A major plot point throughout the series is Plankton failing to steal the Krabby Patty formula with the help of his computer wife, [[Plankton and Karen#Karen|Karen]], under the assumption that they would be able to replicate the burgers and put the Krusty Krab out of business. To avoid this, Krabs goes to extreme lengths to prevent Plankton from obtaining the recipe; he even refuses to allow him to buy a Krabby Patty legitimately out of fear that Plankton might use Karen to [[reverse engineering|reverse-engineer]] the formula.<ref>{{cite episode|title=For Here or to Go|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=8|number=174b|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=April 12, 2012|credits=Writers: [[Luke Brookshier]], Marc Ceccarelli, [[Steven Banks]]}}</ref> Krabs also makes it his duty to ensure that the Chum Bucket never has any business whatsoever.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Plankton's Regular|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=6|number=108b|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=August 6, 2008|credits=Writers: Casey Alexander, Zeus Cervas, [[Dani Michaeli]]}}</ref>
Krabs values money more than his own well-being and assesses the other characters based on their financial value to him.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Money Talks|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=5|number=88a|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=July 31, 2007|credits=Writers: [[Luke Brookshier]], [[Tom King (writer)|Tom King]], Dani Michaeli}}</ref> The only exceptions are Pearl and his girlfriend Mrs. Puff. His love for Mrs. Puff is so strong that it temporarily transcends his greed and drives him to buy her expensive gifts.<ref name="Foy49"/> Krabs tolerates his two employees because they work for little pay and because of their positive impact on his finances, but he is quick to rebuke them if they engage in behavior that drives away customers. Krabs has a tentative father-son relationship with SpongeBob; Krabs often scolds him if he gets in trouble, but at times gives him fatherlike advice.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Hooky|series=SpongeBob SquarePants|season=1|number=20a|network=Nickelodeon|airdate=April 8, 2000|credits=Writers: [[Sherm Cohen]], [[Vincent Waller]], [[Merriwether Williams]]}}</ref> Former showrunner [[Paul Tibbitt]] has stated that this Krabs-SpongeBob dynamic is his favorite part of the show, telling ''[[Digital Spy]]'' in 2011 that "the aspect of SpongeBob I love the most is his undying loyalty to Mr. Krabs. No matter how Mr. Krabs treats him. I try to replicate that in my own life in every way."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/interviews/a312387/paul-tibbitt-spongebob-squarepants/|title=Paul Tibbitt ('SpongeBob SquarePants')|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst (media)|Hearst Communications]]|last=Fletcher|first=Alex|date=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Character== ===Development=== [[File:SpongeBob SquarePants Pearl and Mr. Krabs Early Designs.jpg|thumb|alt=refer to caption|right|An early drawing of Mr. Krabs and Pearl from Hillenburg's [[bible (screenwriting)|series bible]].]] Mr. Krabs is the only character on ''SpongeBob'' initially based on a specific person from Stephen Hillenburg's life.<ref name="minipage">{{cite web|url=http://nieonline.com/coloradonie/downloads/minipage/minipage7.15.15.pdf|title=What a Sponge!|work=[[The Mini Page]]|publisher=[[Andrews McMeel Universal]]|date=July 12, 2015}}</ref> When designing Mr. Krabs, Hillenburg drew inspiration from his former manager at a seafood restaurant. According to Hillenburg, his manager was redheaded, muscular, and a former army cook; these three traits were adapted into Krabs' character, with Krabs' red color standing in for hair.<ref name="Beck84"/> Krabs' speaking manner was also inspired by the restaurant owner, who reminded Hillenburg of a pirate with his strong [[Maine accent]]. However, the owner was not greedy, with this detail added by Hillenburg to "give him more personality."<ref name="minipage"/>
When Stephen Hillenburg first created Mr. Krabs, his and Pearl's surname was spelled with a C rather than a K. Thus, the name of Krabs' restaurant was the "Crusty Crab." Hillenburg changed the name shortly before production began on the show's pilot episode, deciding that K's were funnier and more memorable.<ref name="BoytoBob">{{cite magazine|title=From Boy to Bob|magazine=[[Nickelodeon Magazine|Nick Mag Presents: SpongeBob SquarePants]]|publisher=[[Viacom International]]|date=June 2003}}</ref> The decision to have Mr. Krabs and Pearl live in an anchor was made after production on the first season had started. The original map of the show's setting, which Hillenburg showed Nickelodeon executives as part of his pitch to the network in 1997, did not include an anchor house and instead labeled the Krusty Krab as both of the characters' residence.<ref name="BoytoBob"/>
Mr. Krabs has a distinct manner of walking; when he moves, he moves his feet very quickly and he is drawn as if he has more than two legs. When directing animation for early episodes, one of Stephen Hillenburg's goals was for each character to have a separate walk cycle that showed their personalities; storyboard artist [[Erik Wiese]] designed Krabs' walk cycle with the intention of making it cartoonish. Wiese recalled in 2012, "I animated Mr. Krabs' little feet on a four-frame multi-blur cycle—I think it was the best solution to making him walk like a crab." Steven Hillenburg approved of the walk after Wiese demonstrated it on a [[Traditional animation#Pencil test|pencil test machine]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Wiese, Erik|url=http://cartoonician.com/the-oral-history-of-spongebob-squarepants/|title=The Oral History of ''SpongeBob SquarePants''|work=[[Hogan's Alley (magazine)|Hogan's Alley]]|publisher=Bull Moose Publishing Corporation|date=September 21, 2012}}</ref>
===Voice=== [[File:Clancy Brown by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[Clancy Brown]] provides the voice of Mr. Krabs.]] Mr. Krabs' voice is provided by American actor [[Clancy Brown]]. Brown describes the voice he uses for the character as "piratey," with "a little Scottish brogue."<ref name="Beck86-88"/> According to Brown, Krabs' voice was improvised during his audition and it was not challenging for him to find the correct voice.<ref name="Beck86-88"/> Brown is fond of playing the role, having told the ''[[New York Post]]'' in 2015, "I wouldn't mind doing [the voice] until the end of time. There's just no corollary in live-action work—television or films or anything—to playing a miserly crab on the bottom of the ocean."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2015/01/31/meet-the-actor-behind-mr-krabs-of-spongebob-squarepants/|title=Meet the actor behind Mr. Krabs of 'SpongeBob SquarePants'|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|publisher=[[News Corp]]|last=Miller|first=Gregory E.|date=January 31, 2015}}</ref>
In a 2005 interview with the magazine ''[[Starlog]]'', Brown described his work on ''SpongeBob'' as a "whole other career" compared to his live action roles.<ref>{{cite web|title=''The Carnivale'' actor preaches 'The Curse of Clancy Brown'|url=https://archive.org/stream/starlog_magazine-333JPG/333_djvu.txt|work=[[Starlog]]|publisher=[[Kerry O'Quinn]]|date=April 2005}}</ref> Brown's other acting projects have brought some guest actors onto ''SpongeBob SquarePants'', including [[Dennis Quaid]], whose work with Brown on ''[[The Express]]'' led to his selection as a guest star for the episode "[[SpongeBob SquarePants (season 6)#ep115a|Grandpappy the Pirate]]."<ref name="Beck86-88"/>
==Reception== Critical reception for Mr. Krabs has been mixed, with most criticism directed at his parsimony and the lack of realistic consequences he faces for it. In 2014, Spanish professor [[Pancracio Celdrán]] criticized the positive portrayal of Mr. Krabs' stinginess in front of young audiences.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UCeZAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT218|title=Tacaños, generosos y gorrones|publisher=[[Unidad Editorial]]|last=Gomáriz|first=Pancracio Celdrán|date=May 13, 2014|page=218|isbn=978-84-9060-149-5}}</ref> Economist Sarah Newcomb described Mr. Krabs as a negative stereotype, writing in the [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] book ''Loaded'' that "[[King Midas]], [[Ebenezer Scrooge]], [[Mr. Burns]], and Mr. Krabs are the same recycled character, representing the person who cares for money above all."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8mHLCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA17|title=Loaded: Money, Psychology, and How to Get Ahead Without Leaving Your Values Behind|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|last=Newcomb|first=Sarah|date=April 18, 2016|page=17|isbn=1-119-25833-2}}</ref>
Polish scholar [[Barbara Czarniawska]] disliked the heroic portrayal of Mr. Krabs in the second ''SpongeBob'' film, despite being "a ruthless capitalist who exploits his customers and his workers alike." She later criticized how the show seemingly normalized the character's use of "legal forms of manipulation and exploitative power relations in business."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=32rPDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA131|title=A Research Agenda for Management and Organization Studies|publisher=[[Edward Elgar Publishing]]|last=Czarniawska|first=Barbara|date=August 26, 2016|page=131|isbn=1-78471-702-9}}</ref> Conversely, political activist [[Howie Klein]] of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' offered a more positive interpretation of the character, saying in 2006 that Mr. Krabs is not "exactly an evil villain; he's just a greed-obsessed Republican type." Klein interviewed SpongeBob's voice actor [[Tom Kenny]] on the topic; Kenny compared Krabs to oil businessman [[Erle P. Halliburton]], then called the character a comedic representation of "unchecked, unthinking, unregulated capitalism. Everything [to Krabs] is about the bottom line, not about what's socially responsible."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/howie-klein/who-would-spongebob-vote-_b_29793.html|title=Who Would SpongeBob Vote For? And Plankton?|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|publisher=[[AOL]]|last=Klein|first=Howie|date=September 19, 2006|author-link=Howie Klein}}</ref>
In his 2011 book ''[[Open Court Publishing Company#Popular Culture & Philosophy series|SpongeBob SquarePants and Philosophy]]'', political scientist Joseph J. Foy discusses Krabs' antagonistic side over several chapters. Foy argues that Krabs, not Plankton and Karen, is the true evil character in the series. He also notes his problem with Mr. Krabs' character that "Krabs never seems to learn from the suffering he undergoes, or from witnessing the pain and struggles he inflicts on others."<ref name="Foy55-60"/>
In an article for ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'', Debbie Encalada praised the ''SpongeBob'' series as a whole for challenging social norms; Mr. Krabs' portrayal as a single father to Pearl was specifically highlighted as an example of the show's "subversiveness by subtly challenging the idea of the nuclear family."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2014/05/spongebob-squarepants-retrospective-essay|title=How "SpongeBob Squarepants" Stayed Fresh and Subversive Over 15 Years|magazine=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|publisher=[[Verizon Hearst Media Partners]]|last=Encalada|first=Debbie|date=May 1, 2014}}</ref> ''[[Newsday]]''{{'}}s Meghan Giannotta wrote positively of the character in a 2016 article: "Mr. Krabs ... may be known for being cheap, but he's also determined and a good friend and father. He'll do whatever it takes to make his daughter Pearl happy and he goes to extreme measures to help protect his fast-food business."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/pets/the-coolest-animated-animals-from-garfield-to-scooby-doo-1.10216435|title=The coolest animated animals from 'Garfield' to 'Scooby-Doo'|work=[[Newsday]]|last= Giannotta|first=Meghan|date=October 14, 2016}}</ref> In a review of the season four episode "[[Have You Seen This Snail?]]," television critic [[Tom Shales]] described Krabs as "good-natured" and as one of "the things people love about ''SpongeBob.''"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://access.newspaperarchive.com/us/illinois/arlington-heights/daily-herald-suburban-chicago/2005/11-21/page-31|title=SpongeBob special wrings competition|newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]|publisher=Paddock Publications|last=Shales|first=Tom|date=November 21, 2005|author-link=Tom Shales}}</ref> Paul Mavis of ''[[DVD Talk]]'' named the Krabs-centric episode "[[SpongeBob SquarePants (season 3)#ep47a|Krusty Krab Training Video]]" one of the series' best, calling its humorous portrayal of Mr. Krabs' backstory the highlight.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/66085/spongebob-squarepants-spongebob-youre-fired/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006054710/http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/66085/spongebob-squarepants-spongebob-youre-fired/|archivedate=October 6, 2014|title=''SpongeBob SquarePants'': SpongeBob, You're Fired!|work=[[DVD Talk]]|last=Mavis|first=Paul|date=April 29, 2014}}</ref>
Basketball player [[LeBron James]] has stated that if he "could be any character on the show, [he] would be Mr. Krabs."<ref>{{cite video|people=James, LeBron|date=2009|title=The First 100 Episodes — [[Square Roots: The Story of SpongeBob SquarePants]]|medium=DVD|publisher=[[Paramount Home Media Distribution|Paramount Home Entertainment]]}}</ref> Cartoonist [[Michael Cavna]] commented on James' high opinion of Krabs, writing in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that he found it intriguing how "the gazillionaire NBA hoopster cites his respect for ... the show's resident tightwad."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-20533331.html|title=Absorbent and Yellow and Beloved At 10 Is He|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[Jeff Bezos|Nash Holdings LLC]]|last=Cavna|first=Michael|date=July 14, 2009|subscription=yes|author-link=Michael Cavna}}</ref> Mr. Krabs is also the favorite ''SpongeBob'' character of football running back [[Cedric Benson]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/daily-herald-suburban-chicago-feb-02-2007-p-69/|title=Benson a big 'SpongeBob SquarePants' fan|newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Daily Herald]]|publisher=Paddock Publications|last=McDill|first=Kent|date=February 2, 2007}}</ref>
==In other media== [[File:SpongeBob SquarePants Mr. Krabs and Pearl the Whale Float.jpg|thumb|alt=refer to caption|right|A float featuring Mr. Krabs and Pearl at [[Sea World (Australia)|Sea World]] in [[Southport, Queensland]].]] Mr. Krabs has been featured in various merchandise such as plush toys, video games, comics, and trading cards.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Beckett Presents: ''SpongeBob SquarePants''|publisher=[[Beckett Media]]|date=November 2009}}</ref> The Krabs family restaurant, the Krusty Krab, has been the basis for a [[Lego]] playset<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mi-od-live-s.legocdn.com/bigdownloads/buildinginstructions/4548973.pdf|title=Krusty Krab Adventures 3833|work=[[Lego]].com|publisher=[[The Lego Group]]|date=2009}}</ref> and many replicas at attractions. A float modeled after the Krusty Krab, featuring a [[costumed character|costumed mascot]] of Pearl that greeted guests and an [[animatronics|animatronic]] Mr. Krabs, regularly appeared at [[Sea World (Australia)|Sea World]]'s weekly "SpongeBob ParadePants" parade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://themeparks.com.au/~/media/Files/Shared/domestic%20sales/sw1205603_Trade_Brochure.ashx#page=2|title=Gold Coast Theme Parks Trade Brochure 2012|work=Gold Coast Attractions|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011175137/http://themeparks.com.au/~/media/Files/Shared/domestic%20sales/sw1205603_Trade_Brochure.ashx|archivedate=October 11, 2012}}</ref> A full-size replica of the building was built in [[Ramallah]], Palestine in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/photos-krusty-krab-restaurant-open-719889|title='SpongeBob SquarePants': Real-Life Krusty Krab Restaurant to Open in Palestine|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=July 21, 2014|accessdate=August 12, 2014|author=Nordyke, Kimberly}}</ref> In January 2016, Nickelodeon's parent company [[Viacom]] filed a lawsuit against the operators of a similar for-profit "Krusty Krab" restaurant set to open in [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2016/01/real-life-krusty-krab-restaurant-sued-spongebob|title=Real-Life Krusty Krab Restaurant Sued by SpongeBob Parent Company|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=January 29, 2016|last=Spata|first=Christopher}}</ref> A Texas federal judge ruled in January 2017 that the planned restaurant violated Viacom's rights to the ''SpongeBob'' property, thus halting its construction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/judge-rules-krusty-krab-restaurant-violates-viacoms-spongebob-rights-963632|title=Judge Rules 'Krusty Krab' Restaurant Violates Viacom's 'SpongeBob' Rights|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 11, 2017|last=Gardner|first=Eriq}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2017/01/12/spongebob-and-krusty-krab-prevail-in-real-life-trademark-battle/|title=SpongeBob and Krusty Krab Prevail in Real-Life Trademark Battle|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=January 12, 2017|last=Gershman|first=Jacob}}</ref>
In 2011, the indie rock group [[Yo La Tengo]] performed a live version of the Krusty Krab commercial from the episode "[[SpongeBob SquarePants (season 3)#ep47a|As Seen on TV]]" at [[El Rey Theatre]] in Los Angeles, California. Included as part of Yo La Tengo's first tour, it starred [[Ira Kaplan]] as Mr. Krabs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lloyd|first=Robert|title=The Sponge and the Fury: Ira Kaplan on Yo La Tengo's 'Sitcom Theater'|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2011/03/the-sponge-and-the-fury-ira-kaplan-on-yo-la-tengos-sitcom-theater.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|date=March 3, 2011}}</ref> Billy Gil of ''[[L.A. Record]]'' praised the performance as a whole and called Kaplan's impression "dead-on."<ref>{{cite web|last=Gil|first=Billy|title=Yo La Tango @ El Rey Theatre|url=http://larecord.com/live-reviews/2011/02/25/yo-la-tengo-el-rey-theatre|work=[[L.A. Record]]|publisher=YBX Media|date=February 25, 2011}}</ref> An episode of the [[sketch comedy]] series ''[[Robot Chicken]]'' titled "[[Robot Chicken (season 5)|Major League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]" includes a skit that stars Mr. Krabs and Pearl. The segment, animated in [[stop motion]] like most other sketches on the program, features Mr. Krabs using crab legs as the secret ingredient for Krabby Patties.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Major League of Extraordinary Gentlemen|series=[[Robot Chicken]]|season=5|number=87|network=[[Adult Swim]]|airdate=February 13, 2011|credits=Writers: [[Mike Fasolo]], [[Seth Green]], [[Matthew Senreich]], [[Zeb Wells]]|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ggb-_zU3yz4}}</ref>
A track on ''[[The Best Day Ever]]'', a 2006 [[soundtrack album]], titled "Fishin' for Money" features the vocal performance of Clancy Brown as Mr. Krabs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/spongebob-squarepants-the-best-day-ever-mw0000543164|title=SpongeBob SquarePants: The Best Day Ever - Various Artists|work=[[AllMusic]]|publisher=[[All Media Network]]|date=September 12, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720091209/http://www.allmusic.com/album/spongebob-squarepants-the-best-day-ever-mw0000543164|archivedate=July 20, 2012|accessdate=August 2, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media|date=September 12, 2006|title=The Best Day Ever|medium=CD|location=United States|publisher=[[Nick Records]]}}</ref> In the [[SpongeBob SquarePants (musical)|2017 Broadway musical]] based on ''SpongeBob'', Krabs, played by Brian Ray Norris,<ref name="playbill"/> sings a duet with Pearl titled "Daddy Knows Best," an original composition written by [[Alex Ebert]] that highlights the characters' differences.<ref name="oxman">{{cite web|last=Oxman|first=Steven|title=The SpongeBob Musical Review: Musical's Pre-Broadway Run in Chicago|url=https://variety.com/2016/legit/reviews/the-spongebob-musical-review-chicago-1201799196/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 20, 2016}}</ref> In his pre-Broadway review of the musical, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''{{'}}s Steven Oxman asserted that the musical's version of Mr. Krabs "fall[s] flat" compared to his animated counterpart, and that the theatrical adaptation "finds no humor or wit or even edge in Mr. Krabs' obsession with money, nor in the nonsensical element that his daughter is a whale."<ref name="oxman"/>

{{Infobox criminal | name = Najibullah Zazi | image_name = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | nationality = [[Afghan]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|08|10|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paktia Province]], Afghanistan | death_date = | death_place = | motive = [[Martyrdom in Islam]], [[Islamic terrorism]] | charge = i) conspiring to use [[weapons of mass destruction]] (explosive bomb);
ii) conspiracy to commit murder in a foreign country; and
iii) [[providing material support to a terrorist organization]] | conviction = Pleaded guilty
(February 22, 2010) | conviction_penalty = Awaiting sentencing | conviction_status = In prison at the [[Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn]], New York City | occupation = Airport [[shuttle bus]] driver | parents = [[Mohammed Wali Zazi]] (father) }} '''Najibullah Zazi''' (born August 10, 1985) is an [[Afghan American|Afghan-American]] who was arrested in September 2009 as part of the [[2009 New York City Subway and United Kingdom plot|2009 U.S. al Qaeda group]] accused of planning suicide bombings on the [[New York City Subway]] system, and who pleaded guilty as have two other defendants.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/16/nyregion/16terror.html?_r=1|title=Man in Queens Raids Denies Any Terrorist Link|date=September 15, 2009|author=Karen Zraik, David Johnston|work=The New York Times|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2009%2F09%2F16%2Fnyregion%2F16terror.html&date=2009-09-21|archivedate=September 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/19/nyregion/19terror.htm|title=Denver Man Admits to a Possible Al Qaeda Connection, Officials Say|date=September 18, 2009|author=David Johnston, Al Baker|work=The New York Times|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2009%2F09%2F19%2Fnyregion%2F19terror.html&date=2009-09-21|archivedate=September 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/21/us/21terror.html?_r=1&ref=us|title=Terror Suspect Had Bomb Guide, Authorities Say|date=September 20, 2009|author=David Johnston, William K. Rashbaum|work=The New York Times|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2009%2F09%2F21%2Fus%2F21terror.html%3F_r%3D1%26ref%3Dus&date=2009-09-21|archivedate=September 21, 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}} U.S. prosecutors said [[Saleh al-Somali]], al-Qaeda's head of external operations, and [[Rashid Rauf]], an al-Qaeda operative, ordered the attack. Both were later killed in drone attacks. Zazi underwent weapons and explosives training at an [[al-Qaeda]] training camp in [[Pakistan]] in 2008. On September 9, 2009, he drove from his home in [[Aurora, Colorado]], to [[New York City]], intending to detonate explosives on the New York City subway during rush hour as one of three coordinated suicide "martyrdom" bombings.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/02/25/new.york.plot/|title=2 plead not guilty to more charges in alleged plot to bomb NYC subway|date=February 25, 2010|publisher=CNN|accessdate=February 25, 2010}} Spooked, however, by surveillance by U.S. intelligence, and warned by a local imam that the authorities were inquiring about him, he abruptly flew back to Colorado. He was arrested days later.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} On February 22, 2010, he pleaded guilty to conspiring to use weapons of mass destruction, conspiring to commit murder in a foreign country, and [[providing material support to a terrorist organization]]. He said he was recruited by al-Qaeda in Pakistan for a suicide "martyrdom" attack against the U.S., and that his bombing target was the New York City subway system. Zazi faces a possible life sentence without possibility of parole for the first two counts, and an additional sentence of 15 years for the third count. Sentencing was initially scheduled to take place on June 24, 2011. Two of his high school classmates who had traveled with him to Pakistan, his father, his uncle, and an imam from [[Queens]] have also been indicted on related charges. [[U.S. Attorney General]] [[Eric Holder]] referred to the planned attack as "one of the most serious terrorist threats to our nation since September 11, 2001."{{cite news|agency=The Associated Press|url=http://www.silive.com/newsflash/index.ssf?/base/national-16/1271260740279830.xml&storylist=simetro|title=JUSTICE DEPARTMENT OVERSIGHT – Part 1 – NewsFlash|publisher=SiLive.com|accessdate=April 15, 2010}} ==Early life== Zazi was born in a village in [[Paktia Province]], Afghanistan.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/26/nyregion/26profile.html|title=From Smiling Coffee Vendor to Terror Suspect|date=September 25, 2009| author=Michael Wilson| work=The New York Times}} He has two sisters and two brothers. At the age of 7 in 1992, he and his family moved to the city of [[Peshawar]] in Pakistan where they settled as [[Afghans in Pakistan|Afghan refugees]].{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1925270,00.html|work=Time|first=Dan|last=Fletcher|title=Terrorism Suspect Najibullah Zazi|date=September 22, 2009}} In 1999, he and the family left Pakistan and immigrated to New York City. They moved into a two-bedroom apartment in the [[Flushing, Queens]] section of the city.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/18/nyregion/18terror.html?pagewanted=all|title=Reasons Unclear for Terrorist Fears |last=Baker|first=Al|date=September 17, 2009|accessdate=February 24, 2010|work=The New York Times}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kidk.com/news/national/61918037.html|title=Feds: Terror suspect's mingling fed NYC threat |last=Hays|first=Tom|date=September 26, 2009|publisher=KIDK.com|accessdate=February 25, 2010}} [[Mohammed Wali Zazi]], Najibullah's father and now a [[naturalized]] U.S. citizen, found work as a New York City taxi driver. From 1999–2009, Zazi lived with his family in Flushing.{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_NajibullahZazi_detentionmemo.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301022947/http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_NajibullahZazi_detentionmemo.pdf|archivedate=March 1, 2012|title=Memorandum of Law in Support of the Government's Motion for a Permanent Order of Detention; U.S. v. Zazi|date=September 24, 2009|accessdate=July 15, 2015}} {{PD-notice}} While he was a teenager, he and his family lived in the same apartment building and attended the same mosque, the Afghan [[Hazrati Abu Bakr Siddique|Hazrat-i-Abu Bakr Sadiq mosque]], as [[Saifur Rahman Halimi]]. Halimi was a vocal pro-global-''[[jihad]]'' [[imam]]. He was chief representative to [[Gulbuddin Hekmatyar]], an Afghan [[warlord]] who was declared a "[[Specially Designated Global Terrorist]]" by the U.S. in 2003.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/news/nation/radical-influences-all-around-nyc-terror-suspect-1.1497258|title=Radical influences all around NYC terror suspect|last1=Gross|first1=Samantha|last2=Caruso |first2=David |last3=Rubinkam |first3=Michael|date=September 25, 2009|work=Newsday|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=July 15, 2015}} Halimi and the Zazi family, among others, left the mosque at the same time, during a leadership disagreement. According to one of his friends, Zazi liked listening to [[Zakir Naik]], an Indian Muslim televangelist who is an expert on comparative religion and theology.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/02/22/najibullah.zazi.plea/index.html|title=An Enemy Within: The Making of Najibullah Zazi|last1=Ghosh|first1=Bobby|last2=Von Drehle|first2=David|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=October 1, 2009|accessdate=February 23, 2010}} Zazi struggled as a student at [[Flushing High School]] in [[Queens]], eventually dropping out. From 2004–09, he operated a coffee and pastries vending cart on [[Stone Street (Manhattan)|Stone Street]] in [[Lower Manhattan]]'s [[Financial District (Manhattan)|Financial District]]. He displayed a "God Bless America" sign on his cart. In 2006, he traveled to Pakistan and married his 19-year-old cousin in an [[arranged marriage]]. {{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2009/09/21/timeline_of_events_in_nyc_terror_probe|title=Timeline of events in NYC terror probe|date=September 21, 2009|first1=Catherine|last1=Tsai|first2=P. Solomon|last2=Banda| agency=Associated Press|work=Boston Globe}} He claimed several trips he made to Pakistan between 2006 and 2008 were to visit his wife. In the course of his visits, Zazi and his wife had two children, whom he planned to move to the U.S. ==Events leading to arrest== ===Al-Qaeda training and direction=== On August 28, 2008, Zazi and others flew from New York to [[Peshawar]], Pakistan, a city just east of Pakistan's volatile [[Federally Administered Tribal Areas]] (the FATA).{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_NajibullahZazi_complaint.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301022935/http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_NajibullahZazi_complaint.pdf|archivedate=March 1, 2012|title=Criminal Complaint; U.S. v. Zazi|date=September 19, 2009|accessdate=July 15, 2015}} {{PD-notice}} The [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] describes the FATA as:
[[ground zero]] in the U.S. [[Jihad]]ist war, and home to many al-Qaeda operatives, especially the numerous foreigners from the Arab world, Central Asia Muslim areas of the Far East, and even Europe who flock to this war zone for training [and] indoctrination.
[[File:Pakistan and Waziristan.PNG|right|thumb|240px|Map of Pakistan and [[Waziristan]]]] While there, they were recruited by al-Qaeda instead, and taken to a training camp in [[Waziristan]], where they received training on several kinds of weapons. Al-Qaeda leaders asked them to return to the U.S. and conduct a [[suicide bombing]] [[martyrdom operation]], and they agreed to do so. Later, he received additional training at the camp on explosives construction for an attack in the U.S., or to carry out a martyrdom operation.{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/kensler/ci_14448091|title=NYC Bomb Plotter Plea Deal Might Help Broaden Case NYC subway bomb plotter's cooperation could lead to expansion of case, charges against others|last1=Goldman|first1=Adam|last2=Hays|first2=Tom|publisher=Denver Post|agency=Associated Press|date=February 22, 2010|accessdate=July 15, 2015}} He took lengthy notes and emailed them to himself, so he could access them upon his return to the U.S. Al-Qaeda leaders also discussed target locations with Zazi, such as New York City subways.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_najibullah_zazi_reveals_chilling_details_on_al_qaeda_training_and_terrorist_plot.html|title=Najibullah Zazi reveals chilling details on Al Qaeda training and terrorist plot to blow up subways|date=February 23, 2010|work=Daily News|location=New York|accessdate=February 24, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225001447/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_najibullah_zazi_reveals_chilling_details_on_al_qaeda_training_and_terrorist_plot.html|archivedate=February 25, 2010}} He gave money and computers to al-Qaeda before leaving Pakistan. ====Bryant Neal Vinas==== {{Main|Bryant Neal Vinas}} Zazi met American [[Bryant Neal Vinas]] in Pakistan in 2008.Rotella, Sebastian, (December 7, 2009). [http://articles.latimes.com/2009/dec/07/nation/la-na-us-radicalization7-2009dec07?pg=3 "U.S. sees homegrown Muslim extremism as rising threat; This may have been the most dangerous year since 9/11, anti-terrorism experts say,"] [[Los Angeles Times]], Retrieved February 25, 2010 Vinas, born in Queens, had also traveled to Pakistan (in November 2007) to join a ''[[jihad]]ist'' group to fight against the U.S. military in Afghanistan.Rotella, Sebastian and Josh Meyer [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-american-jihad23-2009jul23,0,4748631.story?page=1 U.S.-born militant who fought for Al Qaeda is in custody]. ''Los Angeles Times''. July 22, 2009.Rashbaum, William K. and Souad Mekhennet. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/nyregion/23terror.html?hp L.I. Man Pleaded Guilty in Attack on U.S. Base in Afghanistan]. ''The New York Times'' July 22, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_Vinas_guiltytranscript.pdf|title=Transcript of Guilty Plea; U.S. v John Doe; Sealed Pages|date=January 28, 2009|publisher=US District Court, Eastern District of NY|accessdate=February 26, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806082922/http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_Vinas_guiltytranscript.pdf|archivedate=August 6, 2009|df=}} Vinas was also recruited by al-Qaeda, and taken to a training camp in Waziristan. There, he also underwent weapons and explosives training (from late 2007 through August 2008). A senior al-Qaeda leader also discussed the operation of the New York City transit system with Vinas, in his case to help plan a bomb attack on a [[Long Island Rail Road]] commuter train in New York's [[Penn Station (New York City)|Penn Station]]. Vinas was arrested in Peshwar, Pakistan, in November 2008, and pleaded guilty in the U.S. in February 2010 to participating in and supporting al-Qaeda plots in Afghanistan and the U.S.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/24/nyregion/24terror.html|title=U.S. Recruit Reveals How Qaeda Trains Foreigners|last=Powell|first=Michael|date=July 23, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=February 26, 2010}} ====Jihad Jane plot==== {{Main|Colleen LaRose}} Over the internet, Zazi befriended Jamie Paulin-Ramirez, a [[Kansas City, Missouri]]-born medical assistant from [[Leadville, Colorado]], who had converted to Islam, according to her family. She was arrested in March 2010 in the [[Jihad Jane]] plot to wage ''jihad'' and murder Swedish artist [[Lars Vilks]], collecting the bounty offered by an al-Qaeda affiliate for his assassination.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,589203,00.html|title=American Linked to Terror Plot Brainwashed 6-Year-Old Son, Family Says|work=New York Post|accessdate=March 14, 2010}} ===Return to United States=== On January 15, 2009, Zazi returned to the United States Within days of his return, he moved to [[Aurora, Colorado]], to live with his aunt and uncle. He worked as a driver for a company named "Big Sky", and then for ABC Airport Shuttle, driving a 15-person airport shuttle van between [[Denver International Airport]] and [[downtown Denver]]. Zazi filed for bankruptcy in [[New York State]] on March 26, 2009, with $51,000 in debts, and his bankruptcy was discharged on August 17, 2009. He lived with his aunt and uncle until July 2009, when his uncle kicked him out for not paying rent. His parents moved to Aurora from New York, and the three took up residence together. [[File:Acetone peroxide.jpg|180px|thumb|left|[[Acetone peroxide]]]] Beginning around June 2009, he began looking for ingredients to make bombs. He conducted several internet searches for [[hydrochloric acid]]. He made some [[acetone peroxide]] for use as a [[detonator]]. He went to New York, where he reportedly had planning sessions with other conspirators. Over the course of several months, the FBI listened to Zazi's phone conversations. In August 2009, the FBI overheard him speaking about mixing chemical substances. It learned that in July and August 2009 he and his three associates were buying large quantities of [[hydrogen peroxide]] and [[acetone]] products from beauty supply stores around [[Denver, Colorado]]. Workers at the Beauty Supply Warehouse in Aurora, Colorado would later tell [[CNN]] that Zazi was "a regular" at the store and had made several recent purchases shortly before his arrest, telling them that he had "a lot of girlfriends."{{cite news|last1=Glaeser|first1=Katie|title=Terror suspect stocked up beauty supplies|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/09/24/terror.indictment/index.html#cnnSTCVideo|accessdate=28 March 2018|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 February 2009}} Hydrogen peroxide and acetone are components of [[triacetone triperoxide]] (TATP; also known as acetone peroxide)-based bombs. TATP was also used in the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|2005 London subway bombings]], and by [[Richard Reid (shoe bomber)|Richard Reid]], the "shoe bomber".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/24/zazi-bomb-plot-denver-new-york|title=Man charged with conspiracy in US terrorism investigation|last=McGreal|first=Chris|date=September 24, 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=15 July 2015}}Conason, Joe, (February 23, 2010). [http://www.observer.com/2010/politics/holder-was-right "Holder Was Right"], ''[[The New York Observer]]''; retrieved February 23, 2010. According to the [[United States Department of Justice]], [[jpeg]] images of nine pages of handwritten formulations and instructions for making and handling TATP and other explosives were found in one of Zazi's email accounts; they mention that acetone is found in [[nail polish remover]], and that hydrogen peroxide can be found in "Hair Salon - 20-30%." Zazi checked into an Aurora motel suite on August 28 and on September 6 and 7, and used the room's [[kitchenette]] to create chemicals for use in bombs.Morris, Harvey, (February 23, 2010). [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1ef782b0-201a-11df-81a2-00144feab49a.html "Afghan admits NY subway bomb plot"], ''[[Financial Times]]''; retrieved February 23, 2010{{cite news|last=Rashbaum|first=William K.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/02/nyregion/02zazi.html|title=Rashbaum, William K., "Terror Suspect's Father Is Accused of Obstructing Inquiry," February 1, 2010; retrieved February 23, 2010|work=The New York Times|date=February 1, 2010|accessdate=April 21, 2010}} Authorities examined the kitchenette, and found traces of chemicals in the vent. [[File:Denver and New York City.png|thumb|290|right|Zazi drove from Denver to New York City on September 9 and 10, 2009.]] On September 9, 2009, he began a {{convert|1800|mi|km}} drive in a rented car from Denver to New York with bomb-making materials. Agents followed him. The day after he left Denver, two [[New York City Police Department]] Intelligence Division detectives asked imam [[Ahmad Wais Afzali]], a Muslim cleric whom they had developed as an [[informant]], to identify and provide information with regard to four individuals whose photographs they showed him.{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_Afzali_complaint.pdf|title=Filed under Seal; Complaint & Affidavit in Support of Arrest Warrant; US v. Afzali|date=September 20, 2009|accessdate=February 25, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/US_v_Afzali_kubyletter.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301023113/http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/US_v_Afzali_kubyletter.pdf|archivedate=March 1, 2012|title=Letter from Ronald L. Kuby to Hon. Frederic Block re US v. Afzali|date=December 11, 2009|accessdate=February 25, 2010}} Afzali identified Zazi, who had prayed at Afzali's mosque, and two of the other three photos. Zazi arrived in New York City on the afternoon of September 10, and spent the night at the residence of his childhood friend Naiz Kahn in Flushing, Queens.[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32845251/ns/world_news-terrorism/ "Target of NYC terror probe says he's innocent; Authorities warn police to be on look out for bomb materials"], ''[[MSNBC]]'', September 15, 2009. Retrieved February 23, 2010 He intended to finish building the bomb that weekend. ===Bombing plot=== {{see also|2009 New York City Subway and United Kingdom plot}} The plan was for him and two high school friends to conduct coordinated suicide bombings early in the week. {{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com//frameset.aspx/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.msnbc.msn.com%2Fid%2F36424437%2Fns%2Fus_news-security%2F |title=Zazi Plot Planned Attacks on Busiest Subway Stations NBC April 12, 2010 |work=Newsweek |accessdate=April 21, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} They planned to detonate [[backpack bomb]]s on [[New York City Subway]] trains near New York's two busiest subway stations, the [[Grand Central – 42nd Street (New York City Subway)|Grand Central]] and [[Times Square – 42nd Street (New York City Subway)|Times Square]] stations in Manhattan, during [[rush hour]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/04/12/2010-04-12_zazi_pals_planned_rushhour_attack_on_2_busiest_subway_stations.html |title=Zazi, Al Qaeda pals planned rush-hour attack on Grand Central, Times Square subway stations |work=Daily News|location=New York |date= April 11, 2010|accessdate=April 12, 2010 | first=John | last=Marzulli}}{{cite web|last=Dienst |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local-beat/Zazi-Subway-Bomb-Plot-Would-Have-Involved-Suicide-Bombers-85124172.html |title=Zazi Subway Terror Plot Would Have Involved Suicide Bombers; Pleads guilty to terror conspiracy charges, cooperating with feds |publisher=NBC |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 21, 2010}} They planned to board the middle of packed trains on the {{NYCS|1}}, {{NYCS|2}}, {{NYCS|3}}, and/or {{NYCS|6}} trains, to cause maximum casualties. Zazi rode the subway numerous times to try to determine where to set off the bombs. According to ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'', authorities believe Zazi was possibly planning an attack using backpack bombs, as previously used in the [[2004 Madrid train bombings|Madrid]] and [[7 July 2005 London bombings|London]] bombings. {{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1925270,00.html?xid=rss-topstories| title=Terrorism Suspect Najibullah Zazi| date=September 22, 2009| author=Dan Fletcher| work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.time.com%2Ftime%2Fnation%2Farticle%2F0%2C8599%2C1925270%2C00.html%3Fxid%3Drss-topstories&date=2009-09-22| archivedate=September 22, 2009| deadurl=yes| df=}} ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that the plot had been uncovered by [[Scotland Yard]], which intercepted an e-mail from a senior al-Qaeda member in Pakistan to Zazi, instructing him how to implement his attack.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6529436/British-spies-help-prevent-al-Qaeda-inspired-attack-on-New-York-subway.html| title=British spies help prevent al Qaeda-inspired attack on New York Subway| work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]| date=November 9, 2009| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.telegraph.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworldnews%2Fnorthamerica%2Fusa%2F6529436%2FBritish-spies-help-prevent-al-Qaeda-inspired-attack-on-New-York-subway.html&date=2009-11-16| archivedate=November 16, 2009| location=London| deadurl=yes| df=}} The e-mail was intercepted as part of "[[Operation Pathway]]". Scotland Yard notified the FBI, which led to the operation that resulted in his arrest. ===Capture=== On September 10, as he crossed the [[George Washington Bridge]] headed for New York City, Zazi was pulled over by [[Port Authority Police]], acting at the FBI's request, for what he was told was a routine random drug search, and his car was searched.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/216262/page/1|title=Inside the Zazi Takedown; The arrest of Najibullah Zazi shows an encouraging level of cooperation between NYC police and the Feds.|last=Dickey|first=Christopher|date=September 26, 2009|work=Newsweek|accessdate=February 25, 2010}} They did not find anything of note, and he was allowed to go. {{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gWpIW42vI8B2yKi_g5oiJUvCBoCwD9B41TM80 |title=Radical influences all around NYC terror suspect |agency=Associated Press |date=October 4, 2009 |last1=Gross |first1=Samantha |last2=Caruso |first2=David |last3=Rubinkam |first3=Michael |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fhostednews%2Fap%2Farticle%2FALeqM5gWpIW42vI8B2yKi_g5oiJUvCBoCwD9B41TM80&date=2009-10-04 |archivedate=October 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Afzali's lawyer later wrote the court: "Even though [Zazi] is not the brightest bulb in the terrorist chandelier, the thinly-transparent ruse of a 'random' checkpoint stop did not fool him." On September 11, Afzali called Zazi's father. Zazi's father then spoke with Zazi, told him that "they" had shown Afzali his photos and photos of others, said Afzali would call him and he should speak with him as soon as possible, and added "So, before anything else, speak with [Afzali]. See if you need to go to [Afzali] or to make ... yourself aware, hire an attorney." Afzali called Zazi, and told him that the authorities had asked him about "you guys." He also asked Zazi for the telephone number of one of the other men whose photos he had been shown, and set up a meeting with him. Later that day, Zazi's rental car was towed due to a parking violation, and was searched. Agents found a laptop with a [[JPEG]] image of nine handwritten pages on how to make initiating explosives, main [[explosive charge]]s, [[detonator]]s, and [[fuse (explosives)|fuse]]s. The FBI asserted the nine pages of handwritten notes were in Zazi's handwriting.{{cite news| url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090920/ap_on_re_us/us_nyc_terror| title=FBI: Notes on bomb-making in Zazi's handwriting| date=September 20, 2009| author=P. Solomon Banda, Steven K. Paulson| publisher=[[Yahoo News]]| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.yahoo.com%2Fs%2Fap%2F20090920%2Fap_on_re_us%2Fus_nyc_terror&date=2009-09-22| archivedate=September 22, 2009| deadurl=yes| df=}} Zazi called Afzali, said his car had been stolen and he feared he was being "watched", and that the people watching him took his car. Afzali asked if there was any "evidence" in the car, and Zazi said no. When Zazi realized they were under investigation, the group threw away their bomb-making materials. ===Arrest and incarceration=== On September 12, Zazi flew back to Denver. FBI agents searched several homes in New York on September 14, and found his fingerprints on an electronic scale and several [[AA batteries]] at the home he had stayed at in Queens, as well as a dozen black backpacks.Hays, Tom (October 1, 2009). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/8733447 "Officials: NY men being watched in terrorism probe"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', Retrieved July 15, 2015 An alert was issued to American law enforcement officials to be on the lookout for hydrogen peroxide-based bombs. On September 16, Zazi voluntarily appeared and was interviewed by members of the [[Joint Terrorism Task Force]] at the Denver FBI offices in the presence of his lawyer. During his eight-hour interview, he denied knowing anything about the nine-page handwritten document found on his [[hard drive]], and speculated he must have accidentally downloaded it in August as part of a religious book which he had downloaded and later deleted. In subsequent interviews on September 17 and 18, however, he acknowledged receiving explosives and [[Military drill|weapons training]] in the tribal areas of Pakistan. On September 19, 2009, authorities arrested Zazi, and on September 21 they charged him in the [[United States District Court for the District of Colorado]] with [[making false statements]] in a matter involving international and domestic terrorism. ==Charges== [[Image:Fed29jail5bbtjeh.JPG|thumb|[[Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn]]]] ===Najibullah Zazi=== New charges and allegations were filed against Zazi in the [[Eastern District of New York]] on September 23, 2009, and the prior charges dropped. {{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE58N3LB20090925?sp=true| title=U.S. charges Afghan-born man with bombing plot| date=September 24, 2009| author=Edith Nolan| agency=Reuters| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.reuters.com%2Farticle%2FnewsOne%2FidUSTRE58N3LB20090925%3Fsp%3Dtrue&date=2009-09-25| archivedate=September 25, 2009| deadurl=yes| df=}} A federal [[grand jury]] there returned an indictment charging him with [[conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]] to use [[weapons of mass destruction]]. {{cite news |url = http://image.guardian.co.uk/sys-files/Guardian/documents/2009/09/24/zazi_indictment.pdf |title = United States of America v. Najibullah Zazi: Conspiracy to use Weapons of Mass Destruction |date = September 24, 2009 |author = Benton J. Campbell |publisher = [[United States Department of Justice]] |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fimage.guardian.co.uk%2Fsys-files%2FGuardian%2Fdocuments%2F2009%2F09%2F24%2Fzazi_indictment.pdf&date=2009-09-25 |archivedate = September 25, 2009 |location = London |deadurl = yes |df = }} {{cite news| url=http://image.guardian.co.uk/sys-files/Guardian/documents/2009/09/24/detentionmotion_zazi.pdf| title=United States of America v. Najibullah Zazi: Detention Motion| date=September 24, 2009| author=Benton J. Campbell| publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]]| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fimage.guardian.co.uk%2Fsys-files%2FGuardian%2Fdocuments%2F2009%2F09%2F24%2Fdetentionmotion_zazi.pdf&date=2009-09-25| archivedate=September 25, 2009| location=London| deadurl=yes| df=}} Zazi was initially held as a [[Federal Bureau of Prisons|federal inmate]] (registration # 36553-013) at the [[Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn]]."[http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&FirstName=Najibullah&Middle=&LastName=Zazi&Race=U&Sex=U&Age=&x=0&y=0 Najibullah Zazi]." [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]. Retrieved January 16, 2010. He was held without bail, and was initially scheduled to be sentenced June 25, 2010.{{cite web|author=  |url=http://www.ny1.com/8-queens-news-content/top_stories/114512/queens-imam-involved-in-terror-plot-appears-in-court |title=Queens Imam Involved in Terror Plot Appears in Court |date=March 2, 2010 |publisher=Ny1.com |accessdate=April 21, 2010}} By mid-April 2010, however, he had been moved to a secret location. ===Adis Medunjanin and Zarein Ahmedzay=== On January 7, 2010, the FBI also arrested two of his high school classmates from Queens, Adis Medunjanin and Zarein Ahmedzay, who had traveled with him to Pakistan in 2008.[http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/zazi-planned-to-kill-peak-hour-commuters-20100224-p2le.html "Zazi planned to kill peak hour commuters"], ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', February 24, 2010. Retrieved February 23, 2010 They are being held without bail. Additionally, both are indicted for receiving military-type training from al-Qaeda. If convicted, the suspects could receive up to maximum 10 years for this offense.{{cite news |url=https://www.euroweeklynews.com |work=Euro Weekly |date=March 1, 2010 |accessdate=March 2, 2010}} Medunjanin is a [[Bosnia]]n immigrant who came to the U.S. in 1994, was naturalized in 2002, and lives in Flushing, Queens. He played on his high school football team and graduated from [[Queens College]] with a major in Economics in June 2009. He works as a building manager at a property management company.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/10/09/us.terror.probe/|title=Two New Yorkers Questioned in Zazi investigation, Attorneys Say |date=October 9, 2009|publisher=CNN|first=Susan |last=Candiotti |accessdate=July 15, 2015}}[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2009/10/10/2009-10-10_feds_question_2_others_in_nyc_terror_plot_.html?page=1 "Feds question 2 others in alleged New York City terror plot; Najibullah Zazi's father pleads not guilty,"] ''[[The New York Daily News]]'', October 10, 2009. Retrieved February 23, 2010 On January 7, 2010, while police were executing a [[search warrant]] at Medunjanin's residence, Medunjanin left his apartment and attempted to turn his car into a ''weapon of terror'' by crashing it on the Whitestone Expressway. Moments before crashing, Medunjanin called 9-1-1, identified himself and left his message of martyrdom, during which he invoked the name of [[Allah]], shouting an al-Qaeda slogan: "We love death more than you love your life."!"—a refrain al-Qaeda trainers use to inspire recruits to commit murder and suicide.[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2010/01/10/2010-01-10_lover_of_death_now_faces_life.html Daly, Michael, "Adis Medunjanin goes from Flushing High School student to suspected terrorist," ''[[New York Daily News]]'', January 20, 2010. Retrieved February 23, 2010]{{cite web|title=Al Qaeda Operative Convicted by Jury in One of the Most Serious Terrorist Plots Against America since 9/11|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2012/May/12-nsd-565.html|work=Office of Public Affairs|publisher=US Justice Department|accessdate=July 6, 2012}} He reportedly told authorities he trained with Zazi in the al-Qaeda camp in [[Waziristan]], Pakistan.[http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-01-11/new-york-man-said-to-face-terror-charge-in-n-y-plot-correct-.html "New York Man Said to Face Terror Charge in N.Y. Plot"], ''[[Business Week]]'', January 11, 2010. Retrieved February 23, 2010 He reportedly discussed possible target locations in [[Manhattan]], including the subway system, [[Grand Central Station]], the [[New York Stock Exchange]], [[Times Square]], and movie theaters to carry out suicide bombings during the Muslim holiday of [[Ramadan]]. He pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy to kill U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan, and receiving military-style training from al-Qaeda. On February 25, 2010, he pleaded not guilty to additional charges of conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction, conspiracy to commit murder in a foreign country, and providing material support to al-Qaeda.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/2-indicted-in-foiled-nyc-subway-bomb-plot-case/article/16766|title=2 Indicted in Foiled NYC Subway Bomb Plot Case|date= February 25, 2010|work=Washington Examiner|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=July 15, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/crime/pals-wannabe-terrorist-najibullah-zazi-charged-nyc-subway-bomb-plot-inspired-london-attack-article-1.169313|title=Pals of wannabe terrorist Najibullah Zazi charged in NYC subway bomb plot, inspired by London attack |work=New York Daily News|last=Marzulli |first=John|date=February 25, 2010|accessdate=July 15, 2015}} He faces life in prison if convicted.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/26/nyregion/26terror.html|title=Two Men Face New Charges in Subway Bomb Plot|last=Sulzberger|first=A.G.|date=February 25, 2010|accessdate=February 25, 2010 | work=The New York Times}} =====Conviction of Medunjanin===== On May 21, 2012, Medunjanin was found guilty of conspiring to use weapons of mass destruction, conspiring to commit murder of U.S. military personnel abroad, providing and conspiring to provide material support to al-Qaeda, receiving military training from al-Qaeda, conspiring and attempting to commit an act of terrorism transcending national boundaries, and using firearms and destructive devices in relation to these offenses. On November 16, 2012, United States federal judge [[John Gleeson (judge)|John Gleeson]] sentenced him to life imprisonment. When asked if he had anything to say, Medunjanin responded by reciting several verses from the [[Quran]] before launching into a critique of [[Foreign policy of the United States|US foreign policy]].{{cite web|title=New York bomb plotter Adis Medunjanin sentenced to life|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-20371785|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=November 16, 2012}} ====Zarein Ahmedzay==== Ahmedzay, a New York City cab driver born in Afghanistan and living in Flushing, Queens, tested to become a city firefighter in 2007.Hays, Tom (October 9, 2009). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/8748531 "Feds question 2 others in NYC terror plot"],'' [[The Guardian]]'', Retrieved February 23, 2010 He initially pleaded not guilty to a charge of making false statements to the FBI about his activities in Pakistan and Afghanistan.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/10/nyregion/10terror.html|title=Officials Focus on New Suspects in Terror Case|last=Raushbaum|first=William K.|author2=Johnston, David|date=October 9, 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=February 24, 2010}} On February 25, 2010, he also pleaded not guilty to additional charges of conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction, conspiracy to commit murder in a foreign country, and providing material support to al-Qaida. However, on April 23, he pleaded guilty to the charges. He told the court that two Senior Al-Qaeda leaders sought him out because of his familiarity with New York, that the leaders "said the most important thing was to hit well-known structures and to maximize the number of casualties," he made the decision to attack the subways, a decision that was based on the amount of explosives. He met with [[al-Qaeda]] leaders [[Saleh al-Somali]] and [[Rashid Rauf]], who explained that Najibullah Zazi, Zarein Ahmedzay, and Medunjanin "would be more useful to al-Qaeda and the jihad by returning to New York and conducting terrorist attacks." He traveled to [[Waziristan]] for terrorist training and discussed possible target locations in [[Manhattan]], including the subway system, [[Grand Central Station]], the [[New York Stock Exchange]], [[Times Square]], and movie theaters to carry out suicide bombings during the Muslim holiday of [[Ramadan]]. His motive was to end alleged wars against Islam. At one point he had doubts, but later resolved to carry out the plot. He then claimed "the real enemies of this country are the ones destroying this country from within. And I believe these are the special group, the Zionist Jews, I believe, who want a permanent shadow government within the government of the United States of America."{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/24/nyregion/24zarien.html|title=Government Says Al Qaeda Ordered New York Bombings|first1=William K.|last1=Rashbaum|first2=Karen|last2=Zraick|date=23 April 2010|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}} He faces life in prison if convicted. ===Mohammed Wali Zazi=== {{main|Mohammed Wali Zazi}} On September 19, 2009, authorities also arrested his father, Mohammed Wali Zazi, for destroying evidence.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/02/03/terror.zazi.relatives/|title=Source: Zazi's dad, uncle tried to destroy bomb-making chemicals|last=Griffin|first=Drew |author2=Johnston, Kathleen |author3=Lister, Tim|date=February 3, 2010|publisher=CNN|accessdate=February 24, 2010}}Moynihan, Colin (February 17, 2010). [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/18/nyregion/18zazi.html "Bail Set for a Man Caught Up in His Son’s Terrorism Case," ''[[The New York Times]]'', Retrieved February 23, 2010] He was released on $50,000 bond and was placed under [[house arrest]].Marzulli, John (February 18, 2010). [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/02/18/2010-02-18_terror_suspect_zazis_dad_free_on_bail.html "Mohammed Wali Zazi, father of terror suspect Najibullah Zazi, free on bail,"] ''[[New York Daily News]]'', Retrieved February 23, 2010 He was convicted in July 2011 of destroying evidence and lying to investigators to cover up his son's plot. On Friday, February 10, 2012, he was sentenced to four and a half years in prison for obstructing the federal investigation of his son.{{cite news|last=Secret|first=Mosi|title=Prison for Father Who Lied About Terror Plot|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/11/nyregion/mohammed-wali-zazi-sentenced-for-lying-about-subway-bomb-plot.html|accessdate=April 7, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 10, 2012}} ===Imam Ahmad Wais Afzali=== {{main|Ahmad Wais Afzali}} American authorities also arrested imam Ahmad Wais Afzali, who was charged with and convicted of lying to the FBI about a conversation in which Afzali informed Zazi he was under surveillance.Long, Colleen, "[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/38101445/ns/us_news-security/#.T6BphOtrO3Y Imam booted out of U.S.: 'God bless America']". [[MSNBC]], July 6, 2010. Afzali was formerly a resident of Flushing, Queens, and legal permanent resident of the U.S., born in [[Kabul, Afghanistan]].Baker, Al; Zraick, Karen (September 20, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/21/nyregion/21imam.html "Lawyer Defends Queens Imam Arrested in Terror Inquiry "], ''[[The New York Times]]'', Retrieved February 23, 2010 He was an imam at a Queens mosque, and ran the Islamic Burial Funeral Service, a Queens funeral parlor.{{cite news|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/FeaturedDocs/US_v_NajibullahZazi_dojprarrest.pdf|title=Three Arrested in Ongoing Terror Investigation|date=September 20, 2009|publisher=U.S. Department of Justice|accessdate=February 25, 2010}}Johnson, Carrie (October 11, 2009). [http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2009/10/11/fbi_police_strive_to_engender_trust_from_us_muslims/ "FBI, police strive to engender trust from US Muslims; Fine line amid investigations"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Retrieved January 23, 2010 He was charged with having told Zazi that he was being watched, and lying to the FBI in a matter involving terrorism.[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,552881,00.html "NYC Terror Suspect Held Without Bail in Connection to Alleged Transit Bomb Plot"], Fox News, September 21, 2009, accessed February 23, 2010 He initially pleaded not guilty, faced up to eight years in prison and [[deportation]] if convicted, and was freed on $1.5 million bail.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1253062/Afghan-immigrant-Najibullah-Zazi-admits-New-York-subway-bomb-plot.html|title=Afghan man admits plotting to blow up New York's subway system|date=February 23, 2010|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=February 24, 2010 | location=London}}Marzulli, John, (November 3, 2009). [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2009/11/02/2009-11-02_imam_ahmad_afazali_pleads_not_guilty_to_new_york_terror_probe_charges.html "Imam Ahmad Afazali pleads not guilty to New York terror probe charges"], ''[[New York Daily News]]'', Retrieved February 23, 2010{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/03/02/new.york.terror.plot/?hpt=Sbin |author=Candiotti, Susan |title=Man charged in terror plot to plead guilty, sources say |publisher=CNN |date=March 2, 2010 |accessdate=April 21, 2010}} On March 4, in a [[plea bargain]] he pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of lying to U.S. federal agents, and said he was sorry.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704187204575101981933707478?mod=WSJ_hpp_MIDDLTopStories|title=Imam Pleads Guilty in New York Terror Case |last=Efrati|first=Amir|date=March 4, 2010|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=March 6, 2010}} Afzali faced up to six months in prison, and as part of the plea arrangement the government agreed not to request any jail time.Sulzberger, A.G., (March 4, 2010). "[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/05/nyregion/05terror.html Imam Snared in Terror Plot Admits He Lied to the F.B.I.]", ''[[The New York Times]]'', Retrieved March 5, 2010 Brooklyn federal judge [[Frederic Block]] will sentence him on April 8.[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6234UK20100304 "Imam pleads guilty in New York subway bomb plot"], ''[[Reuters]]'', March 4, 2010. Retrieved March 5, 2010 As part of his plea agreement, Afzali voluntarily left the U.S. in July 2010, within 90 days of his conviction.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-04/afzali-admits-he-lied-during-subway-bomb-plot-probe-update2-.html|title=Afzali Admits He Lied During Subway Bomb Plot Probe|last=Hurtado |first=Patricia|date=March 4, 2010|work=Business Week|accessdate=March 6, 2010}} As a [[felony|felon]] and under the terms of his plea bargain Afzali may not return to the U.S. unless given special permission.{{cite web |author=  |url=http://www.ny1.com/8-queens-news-content/top_stories/114628/queens-imam-linked-to-subway-bomb-plot-due-back-in-court |title="Queens Imam Agrees To Plea Deal in Subway Bomb Plot", ''NY1 News'', March 4, 2010. Retrieved March 4, 2010 |publisher=Ny1.com |accessdate=April 21, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=BabbaQ |fix-attempted=yes }} Afzali denied any intention of aiding terrorism or misleading authorities, and according to his lawyer he was "caught in a turf war between the NYPD and the FBI." His last words in the United States were "God Bless America," according to his lawyer. ===Naqib Jaji=== Zazi's uncle by marriage, Naqib Jaji, had lived in Queens before moving to Colorado.{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/28/nyregion/28zazi.html|title=Uncle Who Vouched for Terror Suspect Arrested |last=Rashbaum|first=William K.|date=January 27, 2010|accessdate=February 25, 2010 | work=The New York Times}} He was also arrested. Jaji was brought before a judge in closed proceedings on January 14, 2010. He is believed to have pleaded not guilty to one felony count for participating with Zazi's father in the attempt to dispose of evidence. He was released on January 22. ===Fourth suspect=== On April 12, 2010, it was reported that a fourth suspect, an as-yet unidentified Pakistani citizen, was arrested in Pakistan. It is anticipated that he will be extradited to the U.S., and tried in Brooklyn Federal Court with Medunjanin and Ahmedzay on charges that he helped orchestrate the planned attack.{{cite web|url=http://wcbstv.com/topstories/terror.suspect.subway.2.1626347.html |title=Zazi: Idea Was To Bomb 1, 2, 3, 6 Trains |publisher=wcbstv.com |accessdate=April 15, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} One or two more suspects are being sought outside the U.S.{{cite news|author=Susan Candiotti, CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/04/12/new.york.plot/ |title=Source: Terror plot targeted Times Square, Grand Central stations |publisher=CNN |date= April 12, 2010|accessdate=April 15, 2010}} ==Guilty plea== [[File:Bklyn fed court Tech Pl jeh.jpg|105px|thumb|left|Brooklyn federal courthouse]] Zazi cooperated after being told that his parents could be charged with immigration fraud. On February 22, 2010, Zazi pleaded guilty to conspiring to use weapons of mass destruction (explosive bomb), conspiracy to commit murder in a foreign country, and providing material support to a terrorist organization, before [[Chief Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] [[Raymond J. Dearie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nefafoundation.org/miscellaneous/US_v_NajibullahZazi_dojprguilty.pdf|title=Najibullah Zazi Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy to Use Explosives Against Persons or Property in U.S., Conspiracy to Murder Abroad, and Providing Material Support to Al-Qaeda|date=February 22, 2010|work=Press Release|publisher=United States Department of Justice|accessdate=February 24, 2010}} His guilty plea was the result of a [[plea bargain]] with the prosecution. He refused to name which subway line was the target of the plot.{{cite news | url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/22/AR2010022201916.html?hpid=moreheadlines | title= Najibullah Zazi, Denver man accused in N.Y. terror plot, pleads guilty | work= The Washington Post | author = Spencer S. Hsu; Carrie Johnson | date=February 22, 2010 | accessdate=February 22, 2010}} He said the intent of his suicide mission was to draw the attention to activities of the U.S. military in Afghanistan.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_najibullah_zazi_reveals_chilling_details_on_al_qaeda_training_and_terrorist_plot.html |title=Najibullah Zazi reveals chilling details on Al Qaeda training and terrorist plot to blow up subways |work=Daily News |location=New York |date=February 23, 2010 |accessdate=February 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100225001447/http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2010/02/23/2010-02-23_najibullah_zazi_reveals_chilling_details_on_al_qaeda_training_and_terrorist_plot.html |archivedate=February 25, 2010 }} Zazi faces a possible life sentence without possibility of parole for the first two counts, and an additional sentence of 15 years for the third count. Sentencing was initially scheduled to take place on June 24, 2011.[http://www.9news.com/news/article.aspx?storyid=159191 Sentencing for admitted Aurora terrorist, Najibullah Zazi, delayed]. 9news.com. Retrieved on 2013-08-17. His sentencing was said to be scheduled for September 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouverdesi.com/news/uncle-sentenced-to-probation-for-failing-to-report-bomb-material-meant-for-nyc-subway-plot/613103/|title=Vancouver Desi South Asian news|website=www.vancouverdesi.com}} As of May 2017, Zazi has still yet to be sentenced, as his cooperation was still considered to be helpful to authorities.{{cite news|last1=Finnegan|first1=William|title=Taking down terrorists in court|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/05/15/taking-down-terrorists-in-court|accessdate=7 July 2017|publisher=New Yorker: Annals of Law|date=15 May 2017}} A year and a half earlier, Zazi's extended wait for sentencing was described as "unprecedented".{{cite news|last1=Gonzalez|first1=Jonathan|title=Wait time for Najibullah Zazi's sentencing 'unprecedented'|url=http://www.packersnews.com/story/news/local/2015/11/24/najibullah-zazi-sentencing-new-york-subway-terror-plot/76347168/|accessdate=7 July 2017|publisher=Packers News|date=24 Nov 2015}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *von Drehle, David; and Boby Ghosh, 2009. "An Enemy Within," ''Time'' October 12, 2009, pp. 16–11. ==External links== {{Portal|United States|Biography|Terrorism}} {{wikisource|Three arrested in ongoing terror investigation (2009-09-20)}} *{{NYTtopic|people/z/najibullah_zazi}} *{{cite news| url=http://www.denverpost.com/headlines/ci_13398393| title=Littwin: Zazi, justice need strong defense| date=September 23, 2009| author=Mike Littwin| work=[[The Denver Post]]| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.denverpost.com%2Fheadlines%2Fci_13398393&date=2009-09-23| archivedate=September 23, 2009| deadurl=yes| df=}} {{AmericanTerrorism|state=}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zazi, Najibullah}} [[Category:1985 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:21st-century criminals]] [[Category:Afghan al-Qaeda members]] [[Category:Afghan criminals]] [[Category:Afghan emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Afghan Muslims]] [[Category:Afghan people imprisoned abroad]] [[Category:Afghan prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Al-Qaeda bombers]] [[Category:Al-Qaeda trainees]] [[Category:Failed terrorist attempts]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism in the United States]] [[Category:People convicted on terrorism charges]] [[Category:People from Aurora, Colorado]] [[Category:People from Flushing, Queens]] [[Category:People from Peshawar]] [[Category:People imprisoned on charges of terrorism]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United States federal government]] [[Category:Male suicide bombers]]
