{{refimprove|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | honorific-suffix = [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Trinity Cross|TC]] | name = Rudranath Capildeo |image = Rudranath Capildeo.jpg | image_size = | smallimage = | alt = | caption = | order = | office = [[Leader of the Opposition (Trinidad and Tobago)|Leader of the Opposition of the Dominion of Trinidad and Tobago]] | term_start = 31 August 1962 | term_end = June 1967 | alongside = | monarch = [[Elizabeth II]] | president = | governor_general = [[Solomon Hochoy]] | primeminister = [[Eric Williams]] | taoiseach = | chancellor = | governor = | vicepresident = | viceprimeminister = | deputy = | lieutenant = | succeeding = | constituency = | majority = | predecessor = [[Simbhoonath Capildeo]] as [[Leader of the Opposition (Trinidad and Tobago)|Leader of the Opposition of British Trinidad and Tobago]] (Inaugural holder as [[Leader of the Opposition (Trinidad and Tobago)|Leader of the Opposition of the
Dominion of Trinidad and Tobago]]) | successor = Vernon Jamadar | prior_term = | order3 = | office3 = [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Saint Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago|Saint Augustine]] | term_start3 = 1962 | term_end3 = 1966 | alongside2 = | monarch3 = Elizabeth II | president2 = | governor_general3 = Solomon Hochoy | primeminister3 = Eric Williams | chancellor2 = | taoiseach2 = | governor2 = | vicepresident2 = | viceprimeminister2 = | deputy2 = | lieutenant2 = | succeeding2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | constituency3 = [[Saint Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago|Saint Augustine]] |office2=[[Member of Parliament]] for [[Chaguanas]] |constituency2=[[Chaguanas]] | term_start2 = 1966 | term_end2 = 1967 | monarch2 = Elizabeth II | governor_general2 = Solomon Hochoy | primeminister2 = Eric Williams | majority2 = | prior_term2 = | birth_date = 2 February 1920 | birth_place = [[Chaguanas]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]] | death_date = 12 May 1970 (aged 50) | death_place = [[England]], [[United Kingdom]] | religion = [[Sanātanī]] [[Hinduism]] | alma_mater = [[Queen's Royal College]] ([[Port of Spain]]), [[University of London]] ([[London]]) | occupation = [[Politician]] and [[Mathematical Physics|Mathematical Physicist]] | spouse = Ruth Goodchild, Shirley Anne Gasteen | father = [[Pandit|Pundit]] [[Capildeo family|Capil Deo Dubey]] | mother = Soogee Capildeo (née [[Gobin]]) | children = With Ruth Goodchild: Rudy Capildeo
With Shirley Anne Gasteen: Anne Saraswati Gasteen Capildeo | family = [[Capildeo family]], [[Gobin|Gobin family]], [[Simbhoonath Capildeo]], [[Seepersad Naipaul]], [[V.S. Naipaul]], [[Shiva Naipaul]], [[Vahni Capildeo]], [[Neil Bissoondath]], Surendranath Capildeo | party = [[Democratic Labour Party (Trinidad and Tobago)|Democratic Labour Party]] }} '''Rudranath Capildeo''' {{post nominals|list=[[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[Trinity Cross|TC]]}} (2 February 1920 – 12 May 1970) was an [[Indo-Trinidadian]] [[politician]] and [[mathematician]]. He was a member of the prominent [[Hindu]] Indo-Trinidadian [[Capildeo family]]. He was the leader of the [[Democratic Labour Party (Trinidad and Tobago)|Democratic Labour Party]] (DLP) from 1960 to 1969 and [[Opposition (parliamentary)|Leader of the Opposition]] in [[Parliament of Trinidad and Tobago|Parliament]] from 1961 to 1963, succeeding [[Ashford Sinanan]]. He was also a faculty member at the [[University of London]], eventually holding the position of [[Reader (academic rank)|Reader]] of Mathematics. He was also the younger brother of [[Simbhoonath Capildeo]], brother-in-law of [[Seepersad Naipaul]], uncle of [[Nobel Prize]]-winning author [[V. S. Naipaul|V.S. Naipaul]], [[Shiva Naipaul]], and Surendranath Capildeo, uncle-in-law of [[Nadira Naipaul]], and grand uncle of [[Vahni Capildeo]] and [[Neil Bissoondath]]. He married Ruth Goodchild in 1944 and they had one son named Rudy Capildeo. He also has a daughter, Anne Saraswati Gasteen Capildeo, born in 1959. He was awarded the [[Trinity Cross]] (the nation's highest award) in 1969. ==Biography== Capildeo was born at Anand Bhavan (translation: Mansion of Eternal Bliss; aka Lion House) Main Road [[Chaguanas]], [[Caroni County]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]],[http://www.niherst.gov.tt/icons/profiles/rudranath-capildeo.htm "Rudranath Capildeo - Mathematician"], Caribbean Icons in Science, Technology and Innovation. Niherst Profile. to [[Pandit|Pundit]] [[Capildeo family|Capil Deo Dubey]], an [[Indian indenture system|indentured laborer]] who emigrated from Mahadeva Dubey Village, [[Maharajganj district|Maharajganj]], [[Gorakhpur division|Gorakhpur]], [[North-Western Provinces]], [[British Raj|British India]] (present-day Mahadeva Dubey, [[Maharajganj district|Maharajganj]], [[Gorakhpur division|Gorakhpur]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]]) in 1894, and his wife Soogee Capildeo (née [[Gobin]]).[http://www.nalis.gov.tt/Research/SubjectGuide/Biographies/BiographiesAC/tabid/100/Default.aspx?PageContentID=580 "Dr. Rudranath Capildeo (1920-1970)"], NALIS. Capildeo was the youngest child of the prominent [[Capildeo family]]. He was educated at [[Queen's Royal College]] in [[Port of Spain]] where he won an island [[scholarship]] in 1938. He attended the University of London where he obtained his [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] in [[Mathematics]] and [[Physics]] in 1943, his [[Master of Science|MSc]] in Mathematics in 1945, and his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in [[Mathematical Physics]] in 1948, his thesis being entitled "The flexure problem in elasticity". Capildeo held lectureships at the University of London, including at both [[University College London]] and at [[Westfield College]]. He also taught briefly at Queen's Royal College (1945) and was Principal of the Polytechnic Institute in Port of Spain in 1959. While Capildeos entry into politics in the late 1950s was because the political figures who entered the DLP in 1957 did not trust each other, and could only agree on him. Though he left Trinidad in 1939 to study medicine, Rudranath Capildeo changed his course of study, focusing on applied mathematics and physics. He was committed to understanding the nature of space and time and this sparked his interest in understanding [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]'s [[Theory of Special Relativity]]. This work led to several new theories, which had practical implications in aerodynamics and space. They included "The Flexure Problem in Elasticity" (Ph.D. thesis) and his study on the "Theory of Rotation and Gravity" named Capildeo’s Theory, which had applications in early outer-space expeditions in the 1960s and 1970s. His political career was unusual, since he was active only during election campaigns (in 1961 and 1967) and during the summer months. His conduct of the last pre-independence electoral campaign, in 1961, was also unusual, beginning with his declaration that because he understood Einstein he could "compress the time" necessary to undo what the sitting government had done. Not only did Capildeo produce many significant mathematical theories and a book on Vector Algebra and Mechanics in 1967, he also studied law in London in 1956. Two years later he was admitted to practice as a barrister-at-law in Trinidad. He founded and led the Democratic Labour Party (DLP) in 1960, and became Leader of the Opposition in the Trinidad & Tobago Parliament (1960–67). With [[Eric Williams]] as Prime Minister, both men laid the foundation for an independent Trinidad and Tobago. Capildeo was also responsible for having the freedom of worship included in the Constitution of Trinidad and Tobago and Service Commissions (because he felt that service commissions would ensure equality and fairness in the appointment of people to public office). The Rudranath Capildeo Learning Resource Centre (RCLRC) is located in [[McBean Village]], [[Couva]].{{cite web |url=https://buzz.tt/venue/rudranath-capildeo-learning-resource-centre-rclrc-1297 |title=Rudranath Capildeo Learning Resource Centre (RCLRC) |last= |first= |date=July 14, 2011 |publisher=buzz.tt |work=buzz.tt |accessdate=July 28, 2018}} ==See also== * [[Capildeo family]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Capildeo, Rudranath}} [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1970 deaths]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago scientists]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:Hindavi people]] [[Category:Academics of University College London]] [[Category:Academics of Westfield College]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of London]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives (Trinidad and Tobago)]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago Hindus]] [[Category:Democratic Labour Party (Trinidad and Tobago) politicians]] [[Category:Alumni of Queen's Royal College, Trinidad]] [[Category:Mathematician politicians]]

page.title: Sam Waterston on screen and stage

revision.text:
[[File:SamWaterstonJan10.jpg|thumbnail|alt=A photograph of Waterston attending his Hollywood Walk of Fame awarding ceremony in January 2010|200px|Waterston at his [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] awarding ceremony in January 2010]] [[Sam Waterston]] is an American actor who made his film debut in the 1965 drama ''The Plastic Dome of Norma Jean''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/sam-waterston/2/|title=Sam Waterston|publisher=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref> Waterston has appeared in numerous films, television shows as well as on stage during his career. One of his early film roles was as a shoe salesman in the television drama film ''[[The Glass Menagerie (1973 film)|The Glass Menagerie]]'' (1973), for which he received a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series]].<ref name="emmys">{{cite web |url=http://www.emmys.com/bios/sam-waterston |title=Sam Waterston |publisher=Academy of Television Arts & Sciences (ATAS) |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=William |last=Glover |title=Sunday: The Glass Menagerie |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19731215&id=nKtVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A-EDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5245,3981537&hl=sv |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |agency=Associated Press |publisher=Google News Archive |date=December 15, 1973 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> Waterston went on to appear as [[Bond (finance)|bond]] salesman Nick Carraway in the 1974 feature film version of ''[[The Great Gatsby (1974 film)|The Great Gatsby]]'', which earned him two [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]] nominations for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture|Best Supporting Actor]], and [[Golden Globe Award for New Star of the Year – Actor|New Star of the Year]].<ref name="goldenglobes">{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.com/person/sam-waterston |title=Sam Waterston |publisher=Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref>
In 1980 Waterston's portrayal of American [[theoretical physicist]] [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] in the television miniseries ''[[Oppenheimer (miniseries)|Oppenheimer]]'' saw him earn another Golden Globe nomination.<ref name="goldenglobes"/> Two years later, Waterston played American journalist [[Sydney Schanberg]] in the 1984 British drama ''[[The Killing Fields (film)|The Killing Fields]]'', opposite [[Haing S. Ngor]] and [[John Malkovich]] – for his performance Waterston received an [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] nomination.<ref>{{cite news|title=Polls shows Waterston, Field, 'Killing Fields' as Oscar picks |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19850323&id=rO80AAAAIBAJ&sjid=bQYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3755,4636688&hl=sv |newspaper=Ocala Star-Banner |publisher=Google News Archive |date=March 23, 1985 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Historical pictures lead nominations for coveted Oscars |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=943&dat=19850207&id=nbpPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gVMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6458,2885944&hl=sv |agency=United Press International (UPI) |newspaper=Mohave Daily Miner |publisher=Google News Archive |date=February 7, 1985 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> His other biographical roles include ''[[Heaven's Gate (film)|Heaven's Gate]]'' as [[American frontier|Old West]] figure [[Frank M. Canton|Frank Canton]] (1980) and as [[Abraham Lincoln|President Abraham Lincoln]] in the miniseries ''[[Lincoln (miniseries)|Lincoln]]'' (1988), the 1990 documentary miniseries ''[[The Civil War (TV series)|The Civil War]]'', and the play ''[[Abe Lincoln in Illinois (play)|Abe Lincoln in Illinois]]''.<ref name="credits"/> His performance in the last of these garnered him a nomination for the [[Tony Award for Best Actor in a Play]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/sam-waterston/6/|title=Sam Waterston|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=March 30, 2016}}</ref>
Waterston portrayed a district attorney in drama television series ''[[I'll Fly Away (TV series)|I'll Fly Away]]'' (1991–93), for which he won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama]].<ref name="goldenglobes"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Bob |last=Thomas |authorlink=Bob Thomas (reporter) |title='Scent' film surprise winner at Golden Globe Awards |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=266&dat=19930125&id=pNsrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bGQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5792,1965644&hl=sv |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=Kentucky New Era |publisher=Google News Archive |date=January 25, 1993 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> In 1994, he made his first appearance as district attorney [[Jack McCoy]] in the police procedural and legal drama show ''[[Law & Order]]''. Waterston went on to become its second longest-running cast member starring in the show till its cancellation in 2010.<ref name=SAG>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/sam-waterston-law-order-revival-793869|title=Sam Waterston on 'Law & Order' Revival: Let's "Break the Record"|work=Variety|accessdate=March 30, 2016|last=Stanhope|first=Kate|date=May 6, 2015}}</ref> The role won him a [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Drama Series]], and several Emmy, and Golden Globe nominations.<ref name="emmys"/><ref name="goldenglobes"/><ref name=SAG/> He has also made guest appearances as his character in other crime drama series, ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]'' (1997, 99), ''[[Exiled: A Law & Order Movie]]'' (1998), and spin-offs ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' (2000, 07, 10) and ''[[Law & Order: Trial by Jury]]'' (2005).<ref name="credits">{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywood.com/celebrities/sam-waterston-57289932/ |title=Sam Waterston |publisher=Hollywood.com |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> Waterston portrayed the president of a fictional news corporation on political drama ''[[The Newsroom (U.S. TV series)|The Newsroom]]'' (2012–14).<ref>{{cite news |first=Alessandra |last=Stanley |authorlink=Alessandra Stanley |title=The final story for a paean to journalism |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/15/arts/the-newsroom-ends-its-final-season-on-hbo.html |work=The New York Times |date=December 14, 2014 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=AJ |last=Marechal |title='Newsroom' renewed for Third and Final season |url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/newsroom-renewed-for-final-season-1201053054/ |work=Variety |date=January 13, 2014 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref>
Waterston has also appeared in a numerous stage productions, both [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] and [[off-Broadway]], such as ''[[La Turista]]'' (1967), ''[[Halfway Up the Tree]]'' (1967), ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]'', as well as ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'' (1968), ''[[Hamlet]]'' (1972, 1975–76, 2008), ''[[Much Ado About Nothing]]'' (1972–73, 2004), ''[[The Tempest]]'' (1974, 2015), ''[[Measure for Measure]]'' (1976) and ''[[King Lear]]'' (2011).<ref name="credits"/>
==Film== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- !scope="col"| Title !scope="col"| Year !scope="col"| Role !scope="col"| Director !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Notes !scope="col" class="unsortable" | {{abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- !scope=row|''{{sort|Plastic|The Plastic Dome of Norma Jean}}'' |1965 |Andy |[[Juleen Compton]]{{sort|Compton|}} | |style="text-align:center;"|<ref>{{cite news |first=Robert |last=Colaciello |title=Film: The Plastic Dome of Norma Jean |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1299&dat=19700409&id=qNpHAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N4wDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6370,5103469&hl=sv |newspaper=The Village Voice |publisher=Google News Archive |date=April 9, 1970 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Nora |last=Sayre |authorlink=Nora Sayre |title=The Plastic Dome of Norma Jean |url=http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-FLvXjAJK-_c/TgyA-Bplj6I/AAAAAAAAMUc/JvHkl6PeHyQ/s1600/plstcdme2.jpg |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 12, 1994 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> |- !scope=row|''[[Fitzwilly]]'' |1967 |Oliver |{{sort|Mann|[[Delbert Mann]]}} | |style="text-align:center;"|<ref>{{cite news |title='Fitzwilly' |url=https://variety.com/1966/film/reviews/fitzwilly-1200421368/ |work=Variety |date=December 31, 1966 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/91564/Fitzwilly/cast |title=Fitzwilly (1967) – Acting credits |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> |- !scope=row|''[[Generation (film)|Generation]]'' |1969 |Desmond |{{sort|Schaefer|[[George Schaefer (director)|George Schaefer]]}} | |style="text-align:center;"|<ref>{{cite news |first=A. H. |last=Weiler |authorlink=A. H. Weiler |title=''Generation'' (1969) – "Generation" returns in film version |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9805E1D7123CEE34BC4E52DFB4678382679EDE |work=The New York Times |date=December 16, 1969 |accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfi.se/en-GB/Swedish-film-database/Item/?itemid=11695&type=MOVIE&iv=Contributors |title=Generation (1969) |publisher=Swedish {{short description|Recuperation resort for Auschwitz personnel}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox |above=Solahütte |image= [[File:Auschwitz Solahutte (34750).jpg|320px]] |caption=General view of the ''Solahütte'' guest-house of the Nazi German personnel and administration of the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] complex during [[the Holocaust in occupied Poland]]. Photograph from the ''[[Höcker Album]]'' |image2= [[File:Jezioro Międzybrodzkie 003.JPG|320px]] |caption2=Lake Międzybrodzkie on the [[Soła]] river at the foot of [[Międzybrodzie Bialskie]] village, located {{convert|30|km}} south of Auschwitz; about half-an-hour drive along Road [[Voivodeship road#900 - 993|DW 948]] }} '''''Solahütte''''' ([[wikt:AKA|a.k.a.]] ''Solehütte'', ''Soletal'', ''SS-Hütte Soletal'', or ''SS Hütte Porabka'')<ref name="United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 2011">{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_53 (USHMM#34749)(view of the buildings at Solahütte with period caption "SS-Hütte Soletal")|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref> was a little-known resort for the [[Nazi German]] guards, administrators, and auxiliary personnel of the [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz/Birkenau/Buna]] facilities during [[the Holocaust in occupied Poland]]. ''Solahütte'' can be considered a tiny [[List of subcamps of Auschwitz|subcamp of Auschwitz]] because Auschwitz prisoners, overseen by [[Franz Hössler]], constructed the rustic getaway facility, and a crew of detainees did ongoing grounds-keeping and cleanup work there also.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=de&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fde.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2FSolah%25C3%25BCtte|title=Solahütte|author=German Wikipedia further reading via Google Translation|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref> Postcards of the era sent by German staff sometimes bore the resort hamlet's mysterious pre-printed [[return address]] "''SS Hütte Soletal''" but otherwise the place remained largely unknown until 2007, when the [[Höcker Album]] of vintage Auschwitz photographs was donated to the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] which then released images online for study.<ref name="ushmm.org">dead link {{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/|title=(1. Introduction in) Online Exhibitions: Auschwitz through The Lens of The SS|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 24, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130903014921/http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/|archivedate=2013-09-03|df=}}</ref><ref>dead link {{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/2008/03/17/slideshow_080317_wilkinson/?yrail#slide=1|title=Slide_0 in Slide Show: Karl Hoecker's Album|author="The New Yorker" re Wilkinson|date=Mar 17, 2008|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref>
Wartime snapshots made at ''Solahütte'' are somewhat jarring because of the lightheartedness of the people pictured: some of history's most infamous [[war crime|war criminals]] are shown cheerily singing along to accordion music, loafing on [[deckchair]]s, or giggling over desserts with female Nazi staff of the ''[[SS#SS Women's Corps|Helferinnen]]'' or ''[[Aufseherin]]nen''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2008/03/17/080317fa_fact_wilkinson|title=A Reporter at Large: Picturing Auschwitz --What Does A Recently Found Photo Album Reveal?|author=Alec Wilkinson |work=The New Yorker |date=Mar 17, 2008| accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/2008/03/17/slideshow_080317_wilkinson/?yrail#slide=8|title=Slide_8 in Slide Show: Karl Hoecker's Album|author="The New Yorker" re Wilkinson|date=Mar 17, 2008|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_75 (USHMM#34767a)(Nazi women camp staff eating dessert on Solahütte terrace railing with accordionist)|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref> Among the SS Officers photographed at '''Solahütte''' were [[Oswald Pohl]] (executed through the [[Nuremberg Trials|Nuremberg Tribunal]]), [[Rudolf Höss]] (executed through the [[Supreme National Tribunal of Poland]]), and [[Josef Mengele]] (nicknamed the "Angel of Death").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_57 (USHMM#34753)(SS uniformed Josef Mengele with Auschwitz Commandant Baer and Rudolph Hoess at Solahütte)|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_58 (USHMM#34752)(SS uniformed Josef Mengele with Rudolph Hoess at Solahütte)|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_61 (USHMM#34755)(SS uniformed Josef Mengele with Auschwitz Commandant Baer and Rudolph Hoess at Solahütte)|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2008/03/17/080317fa_fact_wilkinson|title=A Reporter at Large: Picturing Auschwitz --What Does A Recently Found Photo Album Reveal?|author=Alec Wilkinson in "The New Yorker"|date=Mar 17, 2008|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref> The latter was almost never seen photographed in his [[SS]] uniform with Auschwitz colleagues until the Solahütte snapshots and a select few other images became known.<ref name="ushmm.org"/>
''Solahütte'' is around 29 km (18 miles) by car from Auschwitz. The main lodge building was demolished in 2011, but various side buildings remain, including the cabin used by Auschwitz commandant [[Rudolf Höss]]. The site is located near the bends in the [[Soła]] river where engineers in 1935 finished a heavy dam which created the scenic Międzybrodzkie reservoir lake. ''Sola'' and ''Sole'' were Germanic approximations of the Polish ''Soła''. ''Hütte'' is German for ''hut''. Hence the German name "Sola hut"—even though the "hut" was actually a motel-sized building with a full-length sun-deck porch along with numerous smaller campus buildings.<ref name="United States Holocaust Memorial Museum 2011"/><ref name="The New Yorker re Wilkinson">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/2008/03/17/slideshow_080317_wilkinson/?yrail#slide=5|title=Slide_5 in Slide Show: Karl Hoecker's Album|author="The New Yorker" re Wilkinson|date=Mar 17, 2008|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ushmm.org/museum/exhibit/online/ssalbum/auschwitz_album/|title=Img_54 (USHMM#34750)(view of the building at SS retreat Solahütte)|author=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref> Activities included hunting, hiking, sunbathing, and excursions to the nearby lake and peaks. Villages of [[Porąbka, Silesian Voivodeship|Porąbka]] and [[Międzybrodzie Żywieckie]] are close by—along with the Żar glide-airstrip and the Żar<!-- << main author will make an English article re this topic soon --> peak with its [[Funicular|funicular incline-tram]]. The region was already popular with tourists. Far from Germany and deep in the potentially-hostile [[General Government|occupied Polish territory]], the SS guards and the female typists and clerks of the [[extermination camp]] had few nearby safe vacation options other than going (usually by the charter-busload) "off to the Sola Hut".
In the late 1960s, the Polish Communist Party rebuilt and greatly expanded existing facilities into an elite resort called [[:pl:Zespół Domów Wypoczynkowo Szkoleniowych HPR Porąbka-Kozubnik|HPR-Kozubnik Porąbka (pl)]] <!-- no English article on this topic, wp:notability --> with dance halls and bars plus a restaurant, indoor pool, small cinema, sauna, and a multilevel hotel for key officials.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZuIqU4jq84w|title="Kozubnik wczoraj i dziś 41 miejsc" (a Kozubnik then-and-now YouTube slideshow)|author=Zimor (et al)|date=Oct 2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref><ref name="OZ">{{cite web|url=http://www.opuszczone.net/kozubnik|title=Kozubnik – ośrodek wypoczynkowy|author=Polish Urban Explorers Group Opus ZC Zone|date=2006–2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011|language=Polish}}</ref> Top mining and metals-industry planners and high-ranking official visitors including the son of [[Leonid Brezhnev]] stayed there. However, after the [[fall of Communism in Poland]], the resort became a rusty [[ghost town]] visited mostly by [[looter]]s, [[paintball]]ers, and [[Urban exploration|urban explorers]] poking around [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:O%C5%9Brodek_HPR_w_Kozubniku.jpg the ruins].<ref name="OZ"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=pl&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fpl.wikipedia.org%2Fwiki%2FZesp%25C3%25B3%25C5%2582_Dom%25C3%25B3w_Wypoczynkowo_Szkoleniowych_HPR_Por%25C4%2585bka-Kozubnik|title=Zespół Domów Wypoczynkowo Szkoleniowych HPR Porąbka-Kozubnik|author=Polish Wikipedia further reading via Google Translation|year=2011|accessdate=Nov 28, 2011}}</ref>
Guests of ''Solahütte'' resort featured in the recently documented [[Höcker Album]] of memorabilia owned by [[Karl-Friedrich Höcker]] include: [[Josef Mengele]], [[Richard Baer (Nazi)]], ''[[Aufseherin]]'' [[Alice Orlowski]], [[Elisabeth Volkenrath]], [[Herta Ehlert]], [[Hildegard Lächert]], [[Therese Brandl]] and [[Luise Danz]].
==In popular culture==
The critically acclaimed novel ''The Constant Soldier'' by William Ryan is inspired by the photographs of the Solahütte guest-house.<ref>http://www.thebooktrail.com/book-trails/the-constant-soldier/</ref>
